document.docTitle: Meatopida testacea Kiałka & Ruta 2018, new combination
document.masterDocTitle: Meatopida gen. nov., a new genus to accommodate two species originally described in Atopida White, 1846 (Coleoptera: Scirtoidea: Scirtidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Meatopida gen. nov., a new genus to accommodate two species originally described in Atopida White, 1846 (Coleoptera: Scirtoidea: Scirtidae)

Melicytus ramiflora

Blechnum capense
at night, 29.10.1985 , C & J Lyal BM 1986–274; 1 ex. (NHM): ND (CL 55), Omapere, general beating, 30.10.1985 , C & J Lyal, BM 1986–274; 1 ex. (NHM): ND (CL 77), Waipoua SF, Waipoua Riv, Ricker Track, beating

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11.
Meatopida testacea (Broun)
, male genitalia. A) penis, B) tegmen, C) tergite VIII, D) tergite IX, E) sternite VIII, F) sternite IX. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Body TL 2.4–2.7 mm , covered with adherent or suberect setae, elytra subtly darkened along suture. Apical portion of female elytra without excitators. Trigonium distinctly longer than parameroids. Prehensor with a Y-shaped lighter coloured area.

Redescription. Male. Body elongated ( Fig. 1C ), small, moderately convex. Body yellowish brown, elytra with subtly darkened, brownish suture, legs slightly lighter. Punctation on head and pronotum granulate, strong and dense, distance between punctures 0.5 diameter at most, punctation on elytra simple, distance between punctures 0.7–1.0 diameter. Body covered with rather short yellowish, strongly adherent setae. Penis ( Fig. 11A ): trigonium bifurcate, very narrow, longer than parameroids; pala oval, base semicircular, emarginate, slightly longer than parameroids; parameroids curved inwards, narrow, apices acute (L 0.65 mm ,
W 0.23
mm). Tegmen ( Fig. 11B ) oval with narrow, pointed parameres with serrated outer edges and slightly hooked projections in middle and cuticular ring at base (L 0.49 mm ,
W 0.39
mm). Tergite VIII ( Fig. 11C ) rectangular with rather distinct apodemes, numerous short setae in apical part (L 0.41 mm ,
W 0.37
mm); tergite IX ( Fig. 11D ) rectangular with membranous apical part, almost devoid of setae, with long apodemes (L 0.41 mm ,
W 0.33
mm). Sternite VIII ( Fig. 11E ) transversely rectangular, U-shaped with very few setae and punctures concentrated on apical margin, distinctly wider than long (L 0.21 mm ,
W 0.41
mm); sternite IX ( Fig. 11F ) triangular, 2× wider than long, weakly sclerotized, apical part covered with medium length setae, apodemes not visible (L 0.19 mm ,
W 0.39
mm).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12.
Meatopida testacea (Broun)
, female genitalia. A) genital tract, B) coxites and styli, C) prehensor. Scale bar (A) = 0.5 mm.

FIGURE 13.
Meatopida testacea (Broun)
, copulating pair collected in Waipoua Forest, genitalia fixed during copulation. A) male & female genitalia, dorsal view, B) male & female genitalia, lateral view, C) male genitalia of the same specimen, separated from female genitalia, D) female genitalia of the same specimen, prehensor everted. Abbreviations: cx—gonocoxite, pe—penis, preh—prehensor, s—sternite, st—gonostylus, t—tergite, tg—tegmen.

FIGURE 14. Waipoua Forest, Yakas Track—a locality where
Meatopida testacea
is very common.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. In some specimens elytral suture is not darkened. Broun (1880) noted a remarkable variability of the morphology of the labrum within the series of four specimens from Parua: two had a prominent labrum, and in two the labrum was little exposed. No significant differences in the proportions of labrum were noted in specimens studied by the authors of the present paper.

Biology. Data on the biology of
M. testacea
is restricted to collecting circumstances. Most specimens were collected in forests, and were especially common in mixed angiosperm-conifer forest with kauri (
Agathis australis
) ( Fig. 14 ). Females were often collected by sifting leaf litter.
Distribution. New Zealand , North Island: Northland (Parua, Waipoua), Auckland (Huia, Waitakere), Waikato (Mt. Te Aroha) ( Fig. 15 ).
